overview: You can get Income Tax back or pay less tax if you're self employed, pay your own work expenses, make pension contributions or donate to charity
title: Claim Income Tax reliefs

table.body:
‘Tax relief’ means that you either:

- pay less tax to take account of money you’ve spent on specific things, like business expenses if you're self employed
- get tax back or get it repaid in another way, like into a personal pension

You get some types of tax relief automatically - but some you must apply for.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
^ You automatically get tax relief on contributions to your own pension. ^

How you get the tax relief depends on the type of pension scheme you're paying into. 

##Workplace pension schemes

Your employer usually takes pension contributions from your pay before they take Income Tax away. 

So you don’t pay Income Tax on your pension contributions (but you do pay National Insurance contributions on them). 

^Some workplace pension schemes are run like personal pension schemes - ask your employer if you're not sure which applies to you.^

##Personal pensions

You’ve already paid tax on the income you pay into a personal pension. 

Your pension provider claims back Income Tax from government at the basic Income Tax rate of 20% and adds it to your pension pot.

This means for every £80 you pay into your pension, you end up with £100 in your pension pot. 

If you pay Income Tax at the 40% rate, you can claim back the extra 20% tax you've paid on your pension contributions through your [Self Assessment tax return](/self-assessment-tax-returns "Self Assessment tax returns") if you fill one in each year. 

If you don’t, you call or write to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to reclaim the extra tax you’ve paid.

If you pay Income Tax at the 50% rate, you can only claim the difference through your [Self Assessment tax return.](/self-assessment-tax-returns "Self Assessment tax returns")

##Limits on tax relief for pension contributions

The maximum amount of pension contributions that you can get tax relief on in each tax year is the lower of:

- 100% of your earnings
- £50,000

You pay Income Tax on any pension contributions you make above the limit.

##If you don’t pay Income Tax

If you don’t pay Income Tax because you’re on a low income, you still automatically get tax relief at 20% on the first £2,880 you pay into a pension each tax year. 

##If you pay into someone else's pension

If you pay into someone else's pension, like your partner or spouse, they can get tax relief on your contributions instead of you. 

If it's a personal pension, they'll automatically get the 20% tax you've paid added to their pension pot.

If it's an occupational or workplace pension scheme, check the scheme's rules. If it allows you to make contributions for other people, the person you're paying for may need to claim the tax relief. They should write to or call HMRC.

table.title: Pension contributions: tax relief

table.body:
If you’re self-employed (a sole trader or partner in a partnership), you get tax relief on what you spend running your business. 

You only pay Income Tax and National Insurance contributions on your profits.

You claim tax relief by filling in your [Self Assessment tax return.](/self-assessment-tax-returns "Self Assessment tax returns")

^You must claim within 5 years of the end of the tax year that you spent the money. ^

##Costs you can claim

You can claim tax relief on money that you must spend to run your business. For example:

- wages and salaries you pay to staff
- the cost of goods for your business (like stock for a retailer or materials for a builder)
- rent of business premises (like an office or shop)
- rent, rates, power and water your business premises uses
- motor and travel expenses if they’re only for business (like visiting customers or delivering goods)
- bad debts (money your business is owed but isn’t paid)
- losses your business made in previous tax years
- accountancy and professional fees
- advertising
- business bank, PayPal and credit card charges
- business insurance
- interest on business loans
- a uniform with your business logo on it
- postage
- safety clothing that you need for your business

##Costs you can’t claim

You can’t claim ‘private expenditure’ - money you spend on things that aren’t directly related to your business. For example, you can’t claim:

- day-to-day living expenses, like food or clothing that isn't related to work
- household expenses
- the amount you take as wages (sometimes called ‘drawings’)

^If you use something both personally and for business - eg a landline at home - you can only claim for the part of the cost that you’ve used for business. ^

##Equipment, machinery and property

If you buy equipment or machinery for your business, or things like furniture that you expect to last, you must claim the cost of them in a different way. These are called [‘capital allowances’.](/capital-allowances-the-basics "Capital Allowances - the basics") 

##More information

HM Revenue & Customs has more details on what you can and can't claim when you're self employed.

$D
[Download 'Expenses and allowances for the self-employed: what you need to know' (PDF, 126KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/factsheets/expenses-allowances.pdf "Download 'Expenses and allowances for the self-employed: what you need to know' (PDF, 126KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D
table.title: Self employed: tax relief

table.body:
If you use your own money for travel and things that you must buy for your job, you may be able to claim tax relief for what you've spent. You must claim within 5 years of the end of the tax year that you spent the money. 

^If your employer has paid back your expenses, you can't claim tax relief. ^

##How to claim

If you fill in a [Self Assessment tax return](/self-assessment-tax-returns "Self Assessment tax returns"), you make your claim this way.

If you don't, fill in and send form P87 to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

$D
[Download 'form P87 -Tax relief for expenses of employment' (PDF, 70KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/p87.pdf "Download 'Form P87 -Tax relief for expenses of employment' (PDF, 70KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

$A
HMRC  
Pay As You Earn  
PO Box 1970  
Liverpool  
L75 1WX  
$A

##Travel and fuel costs

You may be able to get tax relief if you use your [own vehicle on business or for fuel you buy](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/relief-mileage.htm "Tax relief on fuel and business mileage"){:rel="external"} when you use a company car. 

^ You can't claim for travelling to where you usually work. ^

You may be able to get tax relief for the cost of [business travel and money you've had to spend on food or overnight expenses](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/relief-travel.htm "Tax relief on travel and subsistence"){:rel="external"} (called 'subsistence'). For example, if you need to visit a client or go to a temporary workplace. 

##Working at home

You may be able to get tax back for some of the bills you have to pay because you’re [working at home.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/relief-household.htm "Tax relief for household expenses when you're working at home"){:rel="external"}

##Tools and specialist clothing

If you have to buy [small tools or buy specialist clothing](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/relief-tools.htm "Tax relief for tools and specialist clothing"){:rel="external"} for your work - like a uniform or protective clothing - you may be able to claim back what you’ve paid.

##Professional fees and subscriptions

You can ask for tax back on fees or subscriptions you pay to some [approved professional organisations](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/relief-subs.htm "Tax relief for professional fees and subscriptions"){:rel="external"} - but only if you must have membership to do your job or it's helpful for your work.

##Buying other equipment

If you buy something like a filing cabinet or a desk for your work - called 'capital expenditure' - you might be able to get [capital allowances](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/relief-capital.htm "Tax relief for capital expenditure") to help with the cost.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Expenses if you're employed: tax relief

table.body:
Donations to charity get tax relief if you make them through either a:

- Gift Aid scheme
- Payroll Giving scheme

##Donations through Gift Aid

Charities and amateur sports clubs can register with HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to be part of the Gift Aid scheme. When they're registered, they can claim back the tax you've already paid on your donation.

The charity or sports club will give you a form to sign. They must also have an HMRC charity reference number - ask the charity or sports club if you're not sure.

^ If you've paid less tax than the charity or sports club gets back, you may be asked to pay the tax to HMRC. ^

###If you pay Income Tax at 40% or 50%

You can claim back the difference between the tax you've paid on the donation and what the charity got back when you fill in your [Self Assessment tax return.](/self-assessment-tax-returns "Self Assessment tax returns")

###If you get age-related Personal Allowances or Married Couple's Allowance

If you get a higher tax-free Personal Allowance because you're over 65 or you claim Married Couple's Allowance, donations you make through Gift Aid may mean your tax-free allowances increase.

If you fill in a [Self Assessment tax return](self-assessment-tax-returns "Self Assessment tax returns"), your allowances will be adjusted automatically if they need to be.

If you don't, call HMRC to tell them about your charity donations.

$C 

**HMRC Income Tax enquiries**

0845 300 0627  
Monday to Friday 8am to 8pm  
Saturday 8am to 4pm  

$C 

##Payroll Giving schemes

If your employer or pension provider offers a Payroll Giving scheme, any donations you give through the scheme will be taken before Income Tax is taken off. 

You'll still pay National Insurance contributions on the amount of your donation. But you won't pay any Income Tax on the amount you donate.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Charity donations: tax relief

table.body:
Maintenance Payments relief reduces your Income Tax if you make maintenance payments to an ex-spouse or civil partner.  

You can get it if all of the following apply:

- either of you were born before 6 April 1935
- you’re paying maintenance under a court order after the relationship has ended
- the payments are for the maintenance of your ex-spouse or former civil partner (provided they aren't now remarried or in a new civil partnership) or for your children who are under 21

Maintenance Payments relief is worth 10% of the maintenance you pay to your ex spouse or civil partner, up to a maximum of £296 a year (or 10% of £2,960).

To claim it, call HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

$C
